utterances: Silicon Valley actually has its own tabloids.
Marissa Mayer has often been fodder for them.
They like to poke fun at her love of cupcakes and luxury.
She has a swanky apartment at the Four Seasons in San Francisco and likes designer clothes.
But a lot more can be said about her intelligence.
She came to Stanford University from Wisconsin hoping to become a pediatric neurosurgeon.
But she discovered computers and majored in - get this - symbolic systems, which combine cognitive psychology, linguistics, philosophy and computer science.
Mayer spoke with me at a live event this year at the Computer History Museum in Mountain View.

And I really came to the realization that I was much less interested in cutting up brains, I was much more interested in how they worked, how they learned, how they reasoned and what ultimately could be done with computers at the time, make us all smarter and make life more convenient.
Mayer would end up with a Masters in computer science.
When it came time to find a job, she had many offers from startups.
She made a chart with the positives and the negatives of each offer.
Among the offers was one from a tiny company called Google.
And my cousin and I actually gave Google 100 times more likely chance of succeeding than any of the other startups.
I gave them a two percent chance of success, where I gave all the other startups a .02 percent chance of success.

Mayer joined Google as employee number 20.
She created the look and feel of its signature home page and developed Gmail.
Lately, she's been overseeing Google's local projects, such as Maps.
Though much is made of Mayer's gender, she is often, well, like a lot of computer scientists, a little oblivious.
While at Stanford, she was reading a column in the student paper about people you notice on campus but don't know their name.
And then all of a sudden there was entry on the list that said the blonde woman in the upper-level computer science classes.
And I thought, gosh, I should know who this is.

And I was like, wait, like am I really - I mean I really had never noticed that I was the only blonde.
Or I never had really noticed that I was the only woman.
Mayer has done a lot of mentoring to try and bring more women into her field.
Right now less than 18 percent of computer science majors are women.
